title: News Coverage 2018 - Stanford Medicine Children's Health
description: 2018 highlighted news coverage for the Lucile Packard Children's Hospital Stanford
cleaned_text: In the News - 2018 Pediatric and obstetric health leaders from Stanford Medicine Children's Health and Lucile Packard Children's Hospital Stanford are frequently highlighted in local and national media for providing world-class, extraordinary care to children and expectant mothers. Following is a sampling of these media appearances. Une chirurgienne cardiaque forcée de s'exiler (A Tribune/Le Nouvelliste/Groupe Capitale Médias](https://www.lenouvelliste.ca/actualites/le-fil-groupe-capitales-medias/une-chirurgienne-cardiaque-forcee-de-sexiler-0f972ca6dcffa6ad3ab4e99f9a00d702) 12/31/18 Article profiles a pediatric cardiac surgeon from Quebec practicing at [Packard Children's](/en/lucile-packard-childrens-hospital). How to help kids overcome their fear of doctors and shots [NPR](https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2018/12/29/677505443/how-to-help-kids-overcome-their-fear-of-doctors-and-shots) 12/29/18 A national survey suggests that a significant number of kids fear doctor visits; 66% of children between the ages of 5 and 6 hate getting shots. [Tom Caruso, MD](/en/doctor/default?id=thomas-j-caruso), comments on how Packard Children's uses VR technology to reduce the anxiety of hospitalized children. Also see: [Iowa Public Radio](http://www.iowapublicradio.org/post/how-help-kids-overcome-their-fear-doctors-and-shots#stream/0), [KUER/NPR Utah](http://www.kuer.org/post/how-help-kids-overcome-their-fear-doctors-and-shots#stream/0), [WHYY/NPR-Philadelphia](https://whyy.org/npr_story_post/how-to-help-kids-overcome-their-fear-of-doctors-and-shots/) Are your diversity initiatives really making a difference? [ Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbeshumanresourcescouncil/2018/12/28/are-your-diversity-and-inclusion-initiatives-truly-making-a-difference/#612a26af73d0) 12/28/18 Ekta Vyas, PhD, director, HR, Stanford Medicine Children's Health, is quoted. 2019 healthcare preview: Artificial intelligence and a brand new hospital lead the way [San Francisco Business Times](https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2018/12/28/2019-healthcare-preview-artificial-intelligence.html) 12/28/18 Packard Children's opening of its new [Main building](https://newhospital.stanfordchildrens.org/) is highlighted as one of 5 key 2018 industry events. 17 inspiring health stories that made this world seem a little less terrible [BuzzFeed News](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/theresatamkins/inspiring-health-stories-2018) 12/27/18 Nurse Wilma Wong and pediatric resident Brandon Seminatore recount serendipitously reuniting in the NICU 32 years after Brandon was born. Elias Aboujaoude, MD, participates in a roundtable discussion about ethical dilemmas that clinicians may face when dealing with teens and technology. 8 New Year's resolutions health professionals are making Make it Better Magazine 12/23/18 Health care providers including acute care clinical nurse Marie Hamilton share their health-focused new year's goals. 12 ways to show up for a friend with bipolar disorder [SELF](https://www.self.com/story/show-up-friend-bipolar-disorder) 12/20/18 [Manpreet Singh, MD](/en/doctor/default?id=manpreet-k-singh), offers suggestions for friends of those with bipolar disorder. It references recent research led by [Alan Schroeder, MD](/en/doctor/default?id=alan-ross-schroeder). 25 largest gifts to healthcare organizations in 2018 [Becker's Hospital Review](https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/finance/25-largest-gifts-to-healthcare-organizations-in-2018.html) 12/18/18 Article outlines the top gifts and pledges to hospitals or healthcare organizations in 2018. The $20 million gift from Tad and Dianne Taube to Packard Children's, is ranked No. 22. #JUUL: How social media hyped nicotine for a new generation [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/17/health/juul-social-media-influencers/index.html) 12/17/18 Article examines the e-cigarette manufacturer JUUL's social media practices, which previously included encouraging social media influencers to promote its product. Bonnie Halpern-Felsher, PhD, provides comment.
